content: I think it's about time that we discuss my gaming table hey guys welcome back to
black magic crafts I've received several hundred questions and messages about my
game table it's about time that I talk about it in detail its construction and
also I want to review it I want to talk about the things I like about it and the
things that I don't like about it and the things that I'm gonna do differently
next time when I inevitably build a new table I'm sorry to say that no plans
exist for this table I decided to build it while I was standing in the lumber
aisle of Home Depot I basically stood there for about half an hour or thought
about what I wanted to build envisioned it in my head grabbed a stack of lumber
came home built this table in I think about three hours and then really rushed
through getting it stained and clear coated because I had a game coming up
that I wanted to use it in so there was no plant it was an improvised build
luckily I did take a few photos of the construction that I recently found on an
old hard drive first let's talk about the actual table the finished product
this table is about five feet in each direction outside measurement with a
playing surface of 32 inches squared this table seats one DM and three
players very comfortably however you can squeeze in more I often play games with
four to five players and it works but it's not comfortable this is really a
table meant for four people to sit at including the DM one of the main
features of this table is that it has a lowered playing area and I did this for
a few reasons the main reason is because of sight lines before this I was using a
platform table that sat on top of my dining room table
and that raised everything up that worked and it was pretty decent but the
problem is as soon as you started putting terrain on it all of a sudden it
was in front of everybody's eyes and nobody could see anything they always
had to stand up to look at what was going on by lowering the playing surface
this gave everyone kind of an eagle eye view of what's going on on the table and
that is by far the best thing about this table the other reason I decided to
separate and lower this playing surface is that it distinctly separates player
space from terrain space I get really stressed out and annoyed when drinks and
snacks and books and all that other stuff starts mixing into the terrain and
onto the battle mat I want to keep that stuff separate especially when there's
drinking involved in drinks at the table by having this lower area everybody has
their tabletop space where they can put their character sheets their books their
drinks their snacks and this area is for terrain and battle mats and minis only
three of the sides of this table are basically just flat tabletop but my side
the diem side is slightly different and it features a slightly lowered surface
where I can keep my notes and stuff and have a bit of privacy when I planned
this planned this table out in my head I knew that I wanted it to have a DM area
that allowed me to use no DM screen I have a love-hate relationship with DM
screens that's a subject for a whole other video but basically I want it to
be able to remove it so that I could feel more in the same group as my
players and also so that my view wasn't obstructed especially with this lower
playing surface the thought was that this little lowered section would give
me some privacy while not having a screen this didn't totally work out I
realized very quickly that because this table was so small that anything I had
here even if the players were trying not to look at it they were gonna see and
usually ID I'm out of a little journal with notes that if someone glanced over
it wouldn't matter anyway and you know my players aren't cheaters they're here
to have fun however sometimes you want to have some mini sometimes you want to
have some Maps really if I had a map sitting here everyone could see it so
after a little while I did decide to make a add-on would screen for myself
again I didn't want that screen obstructing my view so I came up with a
design that was sloped so that it wouldn't obstruct my vantage point but
it gave just enough of a barrier from the player sight line so that they
couldn't see my stuff and I added some LED lights underneath so that I could
see what the heck I was doing and sometimes I use it sometimes I don't I
also sometimes do you like to use a traditional d-m screen when I want to
have a lot of information on hand especially when I'm starting a new
adventure or maybe it's in a new campaign sitting and I want a lot of
information I can just put a normal DM screen in front of me and use that if I
want to there's the option for all three setups I also included some lights in
this table to give some ambient mood lighting and they work okay they look a
little bit better in person than they do on screen yeah we'll talk about that
more in the recap so the actual construction this table was all built
out of builder grade dimensional lumbers just pine
cheap cheap pine it's affordable it's readily available and it comes in a lot
of usable sizes I built the whole thing with a skill saw on a chop saw impact
gun and an air nailer essentially I took two by threes not two by fours and
that's important I took two by threes to create a frame and I essentially made a
you shaped frame the width of that frame on each side was determined not by my
own decision but by the width of the lumber that I had purchased to be the
tabletop surface I bought some 1 by 12 which of course
are not actually 12 inches wide they're usually about eleven and a half but they
vary depending on what you buy so having the material on hand
I made that framework to fit the material that I had purchased on my end
the DM end I didn't have a bar going across the back because I wanted this
lowered area with the frame constructed I attached my 1 by 12s on top then I
used 1 by fours to trim out the perimeter now that's why I use two by
threes to make this because the thickness of a 2 by 3 plus a 1 by 12 was
able to be covered entirely by a 1 by 4 trimmer and that kind of just cleaned
everything up and made it look a little bit more finished the DM area I just
took one of those same 1 by 12s and I placed it underneath mounted it from the
bottom and this created my little ledge shelf for the legs
I just laminated two two by threes together to make square posts and I just
screwed them in each corner I stained all the wood using a grey stain and then
I gave it a heavy heavy coating of brush on polyurethane to kind of protect it
from all the abuse it was gonna get from cups and drinks and whatnot
after that it dried I mounted the playing surface and this playing surface
is just a big square of half-inch MDF that I put black felt on top I sprayed
it with 3m adhesive attached the felt held it up underneath and just screwed
it directly to the frame I also put in these little strips of wood this I did
use a table saw for I cut a little rabbit
the back made a little l-shaped piece of wood and this allowed me to conceal the
LED lighting so you'd see the light but not the light fixture so that's the
construction now the review what do I actually think about this table after
using it for two years first let's talk about the things I like I really love
the lowered playing surface I think it's absolutely brilliant I like having it
black that negative space really plays well with my terrain and my dungeon
tiles I absolutely would implement that same
lowered playing surface on any future table that I build I also really like
that because it's so small it has a nice intimate feel and people aren't yelling
from you know 10 feet away to communicate everybody is sitting really
close together and that was kind of the goal of making a small table
however this table comes with several faults there is a fair amount of things
they don't like about it and now I'm gonna change when I do it again the
first is the size while that intimate feel is great it gets really crowded and
it gets really tight and it really limits the number of players that I can
have for years I ran a game with five players and it was too tight and then I
actually restarted a new group and I kind of designed that group around the
table because I wanted less players so that we would have more breathing room
so the next table I make I'm gonna keep it the same width but I'm gonna make it
longer I'm gonna make a rectangular table it's gonna allow for more people
to sit comfortably at the price of not being as close but I think it is worth
it I also don't like that I built this really fast and really shoddily and it's
kind of wobbly because like I said I just took you know two by threes and
made legs and just screwed them in it's not very secure and this can be annoying
when you're playing I also don't like the lights I like the idea of LED lights
but I used strip lighting that I already had and I don't like that it is
one foot strips next time I would like continuous lighting all the way around
so it didn't look like little stripes of bright light I also think next time I'll
probably do something with some frosted glass instead of concealing it so that
the light radiates over everything more evenly I think that would work a lot
better and as much as I like this black felt it feels nice it looks good I think
moving forward I do as much as I joke about you know people making a big deal
about magnets I think I want to implement some magnets into my build but
I want everything magnetized only from the underside so that you never see the
magnets and I think the next time that playing surface I'm going to make it out
of steel painted black so that I could have magnet on the bottom of all my
stuff and they stick to the board really nicely the quality of the construction I
rush this I threw it together it gets the job done it served me well but now
that I've tested it and I kind of know what I want for a better gaming table I
think next time I'm going to put more effort into the construction use some
better techniques and also use some better material I probably won't make it
out of soft wood that's not really ideal for furniture construction I will
probably make it out of hardwood and suffer the expense but enjoy the
improved durability and quality and of course next time I build a table I'm
gonna better document the process for you guys and probably make some actual
plans that I can share with you because I know a lot of you really really want
them either way I hope this video has shed some good information on my gaming
table I hope it gives you enough info to go about building your own if you like
this video you enjoyed it hit that like button if you have any specific
